questions.question_text:
Express each number as a product of its prime factors:
(i) 140
(ii) 156
(iii) 3825
(iv) 5005
(v) 7429

Find the LCM and HCF of the following pairs of integers and verify that LCM × HCF = product of the two numbers.
(i) 26 and 91
(ii) 510 and 92
(iii) 336 and 54
hints: Find prime factorization of both numbers

questions.question_text:
Find the LCM and HCF of the following integers by applying the prime factorisation method.
(i) 12, 15 and 21
(ii) 17, 23 and 29
(iii) 8, 9 and 25
hints: Find prime factorization for all three numbers
HCF is product of common factors with lowest powers
LCM is product of all factors with highest powers
Use formula: HCF × LCM = Product of numbers

questions.question_text: Check whether 6^n can end with the digit 0 for any natural number n.
hints: For a number to end with 0, it must be divisible by 10

questions.question_text: Explain why 7 × 11 × 13 + 13 and 7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 + 5 are composite numbers.
hints: Composite numbers have factors other than 1 and itself

questions.question_text: There is a circular path around a sports field. Sonia takes 18 minutes to drive one round of the field, while Ravi takes 12 minutes for the same. Suppose they both start at the same point and at the same time, and go in the same direction. After how many minutes will they meet again at the starting point?
hints: They meet when both complete whole rounds
Assume √5 is rational and write it as a/b

questions.question_text:
Prove that the following are irrationals:
(i) 1/√2
(ii) 7√5
(iii) 6 + √2
hints: Use proof by contradiction for each
Use fact that √2 and √5 are irrational
Product/sum of rational and irrational is irrational
